facts.text: Rajah Padmanabha Ravi Varma was the karta of a Hindu undivided family governed by the Marumakkattayam law.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shah, J. Rajah Padmanabha Ravi Varma was the karta of a Hindu undivided family governed by the Marumakkattayam law.

facts.text: Rajah Padmanabha Ravi Varma died in 1961.

anchor.surface_text: On his death in 1961 the appellant his brother-became the karta of the family.

facts.text: The appellant, brother of Rajah Padmanabha Ravi Varma, became the karta of the family after his death.

anchor.surface_text: On his death in 1961 the appellant his brother-became the karta of the family. In 1909 the members of the family, while remaining joint, had entered into an arrangement

facts.text: In 1909 the members of the family, while remaining joint, entered into an arrangement for separate enjoyment of certain properties.

anchor.surface_text: In 1909 the members of the family, while remaining joint, had entered into an arrangement for separate enjoyment of certain properties of the family by different members.

facts.text: For the assessment year 1958-59 Rajah Padmanabha filed a return under the Expenditure-tax Act as a Hindu undivided family for taxable expenditure on property under his personal control and direct enjoyment.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1958-59 Rajah Padmanabha filed, in the status of a Hindu undivided family, a return under the Expenditure-tax Act of the taxable expenditure incurred by him in respect of the property under his personal companytrol and direct enjoyment.

facts.text: The Expenditure-tax Officer added the expenditure incurred by other members of the family in respect of properties set apart for their use and enjoyment to the return for 1958-59.

anchor.surface_text: The Expenditure-tax Officer added thereto 8 29 the expenditure incurred by the other members of the family in respect of properties set apart for their use and enjoyment.

facts.text: The Expenditure-tax Officer served a notice of assessment under s. 15(2) calling for a return of expenditure by the Hindu undivided family for the assessment year 1959-60.

anchor.surface_text: The Expenditure-tax Officer also served a numberice of assessment under s. 15 2  calling for a return of expenditure by the Hindu undivided family for the assessment year 1959-60.

facts.text: The appellant moved petitions before the High Court of Kerala under Art. 226 for writs quashing the assessment and notice of demand for 1958-59 and notice calling for return for 1959-60.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then moved petitions before the High Court of Kerala under Art. 226 of the Constitution for writs quashing the assessment and the numberice of demand for the year 1958-59 and the numberice calling for a return for the assessment year 1959-60

facts.text: Appellant contends that the law discriminates between Hindu undivided family and Mappilla undivided family governed by Marumakkattayam law on ground of religion.

facts.text: Marumakkattayam law applied originally by usage to a section of Hindus in South-Western coastal region.

anchor.surface_text: Marumakkattayam law applied originally by usage to a section of the Hindus inhabiting the South-Westem companystal region in India.

facts.text: Some centuries ago a section of Hindu inhabitants of North Malabar were converted en masse to Islam but continued to be governed by Marumakkattayam law in property matters.

anchor.surface_text: Some centuries ago a section of the Hindu inhabitants of North Malabar were companyverted en masse to Islam, but they still companytinued to remain governed by the Marumakkattayam law especially in matters of property relations among members of the family.

facts.text: District of Malabar formed part of State of Madras till October 31, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The District of Malabar formed part of the State of Madras till October 31, 1956.

facts.text: Madras Marumakkattayam Act, 22 of 1933 applied to Hindus.

facts.text: Mappilla Marumakkattayam Act 17 of 1939 applied to Mappillas.

issues.text: Whether the law which enables the Expenditure-tax Officer to assess tax on the expenditure of all members of the Hindu undivided family governed by the Marumakkattayam law discriminates on the ground of religion between the Hindu undivided family and a Mappilla undivided family governed by the Marumakkattayam law resident in North Malabar

anchor.surface_text: The appellant contends that the law which enables the Expenditure-tax Officer to assess tax on the expenditure of all members of the Hindu undivided family governed by the Marumakkattayam law, discriminates, on the ground of religion, between the Hindu undivided family and a Mappilla undivided family governed by the Marumakkattayam law resident in North Malabar.

issues.text: Whether the plea of discrimination under Article 14 holds in light of the special characteristics of Hindu and Mappilla families governed by Marumakkattayam law and the legislative discretion in tax classification

anchor.surface_text: it is in the light of these special characteristics that-the plea of discrimination must be considered. Equal protection clause of the Constitution does not enjoin equal protection of the laws as abstract propositions. Laws being the expression of legislative will intended to solve specific problems or to achieve definite objectives by specific remedies, absolute, equality or uniformity of treatment is impossible of achievement.

issues.text: Whether a family governed by the Marumakkattayam law qualifies as a Hindu undivided family within the meaning of the Expenditure-tax Act

anchor.surface_text: In a Hindu tarwad governed by the Marumakkattayam law the descent is matriarch-ate and all members male and female have equal shares in the property of the tarwad. Though not a family governed by the Mitakshara law, it is still a Hindu undivided family within the meaning of the Expenditure-tax Act.

Though not a family governed by the Mitakshara law, it is still a Hindu undivided family within the meaning of the Expenditure-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: enacted the Madras Marumakkattayam Act, 22 of 1933 and the Mappilla Marumakkattayam Act 17 of 1939, the former applying to Hindus and the latter to Mappillas who are Muslims. There were however significant difference between the two Acts.

arguments.claim: it is in the light of these special characteristics that the plea of discrimination must be considered

anchor.surface_text: it is in the light of these special characteristics that-the plea of discrimination must be considered. Equal protection clause of the Constitution does not enjoin equal protection of the laws as abstract propositions. Laws being the expression of legislative will intended to solve specific problems or to achieve definite objectives by specific remedies, absolute, equality or uniformity of treatment is impossible of achievement.

arguments.claim: This long course of legislative history in matters of taxing income, wealth, gifts, capital gains and business profits clearly indicates that the legislature regarded undivided families of Hindus as a class to which the legislation may appropriately be applied

anchor.surface_text: This long course of legislative history in matters of taxing income, wealth, gifts, capital gains and business profits clearly indicates that the legislature regarded undivided families of Hindus as a class to which the legislation may appropriately be applied. An intention to effectively administer the taxing Acts and not to discriminate on the ground of religion may be attributed to the Legislature.

arguments.claim: The Parliament in the present case having made the Expenditure-tax Act applicable to Hindus governed by the law of the joint family, but not including Mappilla families who are governed by the Mappilla Marumakkattayam Act has not made any discrimination

anchor.surface_text: The Parliament in the present case having made the Expenditure-tax Act applicable to Hindus governed by the law of the joint family, but not including Mappilla families who are governed by the Mappilla Marumakkattayam Act has not made any discrimination and the charging section is not liable to be struck down on the ground that the Mappilla family may have to pay tax at a lower rate

holdings.text: Though not a family governed by the Mitakshara law, it is still a Hindu undivided family within the meaning of the Expenditure-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: In a Hindu tarwad governed by the Marumakkattayam law the descent is matriarch-ate and all members male and female have equal shares in the property of the tarwad. Though not a family governed by the Mitakshara law, it is still a Hindu undivided family within the meaning of the Expenditure-tax Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Matriarchal descent and equal shares among males and females do not exclude it from being an undivided family of Hindus taxable as HUF under the Act.

holdings.text: Under the charging section tax is imposed on individuals and Hindu undivided families. An undivided family which consists of Hindus alone may be treated as a unit of assessment an undivided family whose members are not Hindus will be assessed to tax as an individual.

anchor.surface_text: Under the charging section tax is imposed on individuals and Hindu undivided families. An undivided family which consists of Hindus alone may be treated as a unit of assessment an undivided family whose members are not Hindus will be assessed to tax as an individual.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain language of Section 3 limits HUF status to families of Hindus only; non-Hindu undivided families taxable as individuals.

holdings.text: The Parliament in the present case having made the Expenditure-tax Act applicable to Hindus governed by the law of the joint family, but not including Mappilla families who are governed by the Mappilla Marumakkattayam Act has not made any discrimination and the charging section is not liable to be struck down on the ground that the Mappilla family may have to pay tax at a lower rate
holdings.reasoning_summary: Valid reasonable classification under Art.14 due to distinct legal regimes (separate statutes), community differences (size, location, Islamic influences), consistent legislative history treating Hindu HUFs separately in multiple tax laws.

holdings.text: it is in the light of these special characteristics that-the plea of discrimination must be considered

anchor.surface_text: it is in the light of these special characteristics that-the plea of discrimination must be considered. Equal protection clause of the Constitution does not enjoin equal protection of the laws as abstract propositions. Laws being the expression of legislative will intended to solve specific problems or to achieve definite objectives by specific remedies, absolute, equality or uniformity of treatment is impossible of achievement.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.14 permits classification in tax laws with wide legislative discretion if rational basis exists in special characteristics like differing property laws, partition rights, succession, and historical treatment.

holdings.text: The appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner's challenges to assessments and notices rejected on merits of HUF status and no Art.14 violation.

precedents.citation: Raja Jagannath Baksh Singh State of Uttar Pradesh and Another 1

anchor.surface_text: Raja Jagannath Baksh Singh State of Uttar Pradesh and Another 1 . The same rule has been accepted by the Courts in America. Wills in his Constitutional Law of the United States has stated at p. 587 A state does number have to tax everything in order to tax something. It is allowed to pick and choose districts, objects, persons, methods, and even. rates for taxation if it does so reasonably. As stated in Weavers Constitutional Law Art. 275 at p. 405 Me Fourteenth Amendment was number designed to prevent a state from establishing a system of taxation or from effecting a change in its system in all proper,  1   1963 1 S.C.R. 220.
